front.title: The Chatroom Relay Role at IETF Meetings

abstract.t: During IETF meetings, individual volunteers often help sessions run more smoothly by relaying information back and forth between the physical meeting room and an associated textual chatroom (where remote participants can send questions or feedback to the physical room).
This document provides suggestions for fulfilling the role of a chatroom relay.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: During IETF meetings, individual volunteers often help sessions run more smoothly by relaying information back and forth between the physical meeting room and an associated textual chatroom. This role is critical as it is currently the only "real-time" way for a remote attendee to provide feedback or comments back into most IETF working groups. While there are multiple ways that a remote attendee can listen and follow along (ex. audio streams, MeetEcho), the chatroom provides a method of returning feedback to the physical meeting.
This document provides suggestions for fulfilling the role of a chatroom relay.

Participants in the chatroom are typically remote attendees who are listening to the audio stream and may wish to send questions or feedback to the physical room. Remote attendees typically are able to listen to the audio streams or watch/listen through a MeetEcho session.

Chatroom participants may also be IETF meeting attendees who are in another simultaneous working group session in a different physical room. They are often monitoring the chatroom session to find out when a particular draft is being discussed or to just observe what is being discussed in the chatroom. Typically they are not able to listen to the audio stream and sometimes ask for a higher level of commentary so that they can know when they might need to come over to the session's physical room.

As all chatroom sessions are logged during IETF meetings and the logs are publicly available, the logs can be a very useful history of what occurs during a meeting. For that reason any additional information that can be supplied to remote participants can be very helpful.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: A chatroom relay is often referred to as a "Jabber scribe". This term is misleading because nothing prevents the IETF from using a technology other than Jabber/XMPP for chatrooms, and more importantly because volunteers are not expected to scribe the complete contents of the meeting into the chatroom (which would be a much more onerous task than relaying selected information back and forth between the physical room and the chatroom).

section.title: Primary Tasks
section.t: Individuals who volunteer for the role of chatroom relay usually complete the following tasks:

list.t: Relay questions and comments from the chatroom to the physical room. This typically involves going to the microphone to relay the comment from the remote participant.
Count the number of chatroom participants who virtually "hum", raise their hands, volunteer to provide feedback on documents, etc.
Relay to the remote participants any logistical or procedural issues related to the meeting. For instance, if there is a problem with the audio streaming or a delay in getting the meeting started.

section.t: It is the convention in most working groups that the chatroom relay has the ability to go to the front of the microphone line to relay the question(s) from remote participants. Some chatroom relays choose to exercise that ability while others may choose to wait in line along with the participants in the physical meeting rooom.

section.title: Additional Tasks
section.t: Additionally some chatroom relays often complete the minimum of the following tasks:

list.t: Relay the names of people speaking in the physical room to the chatroom.
Relay the slide numbers or slide names to help chatroom participants follow along.
Provide assistance of various kinds to chatroom participants (e.g., asking about the audio delay or reporting technical problems in the physical room).
Provide the links to the current set of slides and the document being discussed so that remote participants can easily follow along.

section.t: Although chatroom relays are not expected to scribe the complete contents of conversations that happen the physical room to the chatroom, they sometimes relay the gist of such conversations, especially during ad-hoc discussions for which slides are not available.

section.title: Suggestions
section.t: Experience has shown that the following behaviors make it easier to act as a chatroom relay.
As you are getting settled and ready for the meeting to start:

Coordinate in advance with the chairs of the session to ensure that remote participants have received information about where to find the meeting materials, agenda, audio stream, etc. (e.g., this information can be sent to a working group discussion list so that remote participants do not need to ask about it on entering the chatroom). Also ask the session chairs whether it is acceptable for you to advance to the front of the mic line with time-sensitive comments from remote participants. Seat yourself near the microphone mostly likely to be used for discussions in the physical room, so that you can more easily capture the names of people who come to the mic. Choose a seat near the end of a row or in some location where you can easily get up out of your seat to go to the microphone. It may be helpful to open several browser windows or tabs for:
the agenda page for the specific working group meeting the materials page so that you can relay links to slides if necessary the documents page for the working group in case you want easy access to documents mentioned but not in the agenda page the meeting registration system page (see below)
Determine if the session will be streamed via MeetEcho. If so, the MeetEcho system will be automatically posting the slide names into the chatroom and this is one less task you need to be concerned about. If the session is large or is expected to be especially active (e.g., a controversial BoF), find an assistant who can help you by sitting at another mic, taking turns relaying information, etc.
Identifying one or more assistants is very useful particularly if you want to go up to the microphone to speak as an individual or if you need to take a break or a phone call or something similar.

During the actual meeting:
Identify yourself in both the physical room and the chatroom so that participants in both venues know that you are a relay. Ask chatroom participants what level of information they need relayed into the chatroom. For example if all chatroom participants are listening via audio or MeetEcho they may need very little information relayed from the room. Ask chatroom participants to prepend statements they would like you to relay with "RELAY" or "MIC" (the former term is less ambiguous). When relaying a question or comment from the chatroom to the physical room, say "this is X relaying for Y from the chatroom" so that people know you are not speaking for yourself. It's not expected that you will know the names of everyone who comes to the mic. If you don't know the name of a person at the microphone, look at their name badge, query them directly, or ask in the chatroom (usually some of the people in the physical room will also be participating in the chatroom). Another good practice if you do not know someone's name is to type something like "?? at the mic" in the chatroom, since it is likely that someone who is present in both the physical room and the chatroom will be able to identify the person for you. One tool you can use to quickly look up the names of attendees is the meeting registration system. This is typically found at the URL:
https://www.ietf.org/registration/<meeting>/attendance.py
as in the example:
https://www.ietf.org/registration/ietf90/attendance.py
You can quickly look up a name using this system if you are in doubt. Lag happens between the time when something is said in the physical room and the time when someone provides a response in the chatroom, so take this into account when the interaction is time-sensitive (e.g., during a hum or a show of hands).

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document requests no actions from the IANA.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Although XMPP multi-user chat rooms can be configured to lock down nicknames and require registration with the chatroom in order to join, at the time of this writing IETF chatrooms are not so configured. This introduces the possibility of social engineering attacks on discussions held in IETF chatrooms. It can be helpful for chatroom relays to be aware of this possibility.
